p: Studies using of global climate models mostly suggest that few shallow coral species will persist under a sea surface temperature increase of 2°C in the next one hundred years [ 138]. Nevertheless, given the current slowness in mitigation measures, it is expected an increase of 3.1°C in the same period (RCP 8.5) [ 139]. In such scenarios, identify and protect deep sea refugia must become priorities for species conservation [ 131], considering the various factors defining a potentially true refuge [ 140].
